resources.string: Constantine – The City of Hanging Bridges

It is the third-largest city in Algeria and the capital of the country’s eastern region. Known as the City of Hanging Bridges due to its unique geographical landscape, it is built on a solid limestone rock, giving it a distinctive appearance and earning it the title "The City of Ancient Rock."

 With a history spanning over 2,300 years, it was originally known as Cirta and served as the capital of the Kingdom of Numidia before falling under Roman rule.
 It received its current name in 313 AD in honor of Emperor Constantine the Great.
 Throughout the centuries, it remained an important cultural and historical center, preserving its rich heritage to this day.
The highest bridge in Constantine, standing 175 meters above the Rhumel Gorge. Built in 1912, it was once the highest suspension bridge in the world.
A stunning stone-arch bridge built in 1912, featuring 27 arches and standing 105 meters high. It was once the largest stone bridge in the world.
One of Constantine’s oldest bridges, dating back to the Roman era. It has been rebuilt multiple times, serving as a historic passageway into the city.
Named after the waterfalls it crosses, this 1925 bridge allows vehicles and pedestrians to admire the natural beauty of Constantine.
Originally built by the Ottomans in 1792 and rebuilt in 1863, this bridge serves as an important gateway to the old city.
Located in the Sidi M’Cid district, Constantine Municipality. It connects the city center to the heights of Sidi M’Cid, near the University Hospital of Constantine.
Located in the downtown area of Constantine, it connects the city center to the Plateau of Mansourah, near the Constantine train station.
Located in the Bab El Kantara district, Constantine Municipality. It connects the lower part of the city with the old medina, near Emir Abdelkader Mosque.
Located near the Boumerzoug district, Constantine Municipality. It spans over the waterfalls of the Rhumel River, offering a scenic view of the valley.
Located in the Bab El Kantara district, Constantine Municipality. It serves as the historical entrance to the city, near the ancient Ottoman fortress.

Cirta Museum is the main archaeological and historical museum of Constantine, housing over 10,000 artifacts that reflect the city diverse historical periods, from the Numidian and Roman eras to the Islamic age. Officially inaugurated in 1931, the museum features remarkable collections of Roman sculptures, mosaics, ancient coins, pottery, as well as rare manuscripts and historical documents that shed light on Constantine’s rich past.
Located in the heart of Constantine, near the old city, it is a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts and cultural explorers.

Ghabat El Wahch, meaning "Forest of the Beast," is a vast green space located on the outskirts of Constantine. It serves as a popular recreational area for locals and visitors, offering fresh air, hiking trails, and scenic picnic spots. The forest is home to diverse plant species and wildlife, making it an excellent escape into nature.

Tiddis is an ancient Numidian and Roman archaeological site perched on a hilltop near Constantine. It offers breathtaking panoramic views of the surrounding valleys. The ruins include Roman roads, a forum, houses, and water systems, showcasing the blend of Numidian and Roman architectural styles. Tiddis is an ideal spot for history enthusiasts and nature lovers alike.

Oued Rhumel is the iconic river that carved Constantine’s famous gorges, creating the city dramatic landscape. The river winds through deep canyons beneath Constantine’s bridges, offering spectacular views. It has played a crucial role in the city history and provides stunning natural scenery for sightseeing and photography.
Located on the outskirts of Constantine, it is one of the city largest green spaces, ideal for outdoor activities.
Located approximately 30 km from Constantine, Tiddis is a hilltop archaeological site with breathtaking views of the surrounding valleys.
Flowing through the heart of Constantine, Oued Rhumel is a key geographical feature that shaped the city landscape.

The Emir Abdelkader Mosque is one of Algeria’s most iconic religious landmarks, inaugurated in 1994. Built in the Andalusian-Maghreb architectural style, the mosque features two towering minarets, each standing at 107 meters. Its grand prayer hall accommodates over 15,000 worshippers, and the walls are adorned with intricate Quranic inscriptions. The mosque also houses an Islamic university, making it a major center for religious education.
Located in the center of Constantine, it stands as a symbol of Algeria’s cultural and religious heritage.

The Palace of Ahmed Bey is one of the finest Ottoman-era palaces in Algeria, built between 1826 and 1835. It served as the residence of Ahmed Bey, the last ruler of Constantine under Ottoman rule. The palace contains more than 120 rooms, beautifully decorated with Andalusian-style mosaics, elaborate paintings, and vast gardens filled with exotic plants. Today, it stands as a significant historical site, offering visitors a glimpse into Constantine’s past.
Located in the heart of Constantine, near Martyrs’ Square, it is one of the city’s most important historical attractions.

Cirta is the comprehensive mobile guide designed to transform your exploration of Constantine, one of Algeria\'s most historic and breathtaking cities. We understand that travelers want convenience, depth, and authenticity when discovering a new destination – and that\'s exactly what we deliver.

Before Cirta, exploring Constantine meant jumping between multiple websites, struggling with fragmented information, and potentially missing hidden gems. Our app brings everything you need into one powerful, user-friendly platform.

Comprehensive Historical Sites
-Local Restaurant Recommendations
-Accommodation Options
-Transportation Guides
-Interactive City Maps
-Local Tips and Insights

The Sahraoui Tahar bus station is the main departure and arrival point for travelers using intercity transportation in the region.

Ali Mendjeli station in Constantine is a major bus station located in the new city of Ali Mendjeli. This station serves as the departure and arrival point for numerous trips between Constantine and other Algerian cities.
located in the municipality of Constantine.
located in the southern suburbs of Constantine.
Ben Abdelmalek Ramdane Tram Station is the northern terminus of the Constantine tramway network in Algeria.
Zouaghi Slimane station is a key station on the Constantine tramway.
Chahid Kadri Brahim station serves as an interchange point brtween tram lines, facilitating access to the outlying areas of Constantine and neighboring towns.
Located in Manzar Al Jameel neighborhood.
located in the southeast of the city.
located in the Ali Mendjeli administrative distrinct.

Tanouji Station also known as Emir bdelkader District Station, is one of the three stations of the Constantine Cable Car, the cable car that connects the two banks of the Wadi Rum in the city Constantine.
The Ibn Badis University Hospital station is an intermediate station in the Constantine cable car system.
The Tatache Square station (also known as the Signal Station) is one of the stations of the constantine cable car, which connects the city center to its upper neighborhoods.
runs along the Bab El Kantra suspension bridge.
located in the Ben Seghir Abdelwahab neighborhood of Constantine, near the end of the Sidi Mcid Bridge.
located at an altitude of 619.29 meters, the distance between it an the Ibn Badis University Station is 1,092 meters.

Magic House is a cozy restaurant offering a delightful mix of foods, vegan and vegetarian options, and quick bites. Enjoy flavorful small plates paired with a rich coffee or a fine coffee in a warm and welcoming atmosphere.

TakeOff Lounge is the perfect spot for a delicious meal any time of day. Serving up sandwiches, burgers, and refreshing smoothies, along with flavorful small plates and fresh coffee, we offer something for everyone. Whether you are stopping by for breakfast, lunch, or dinner.

Igherssan Restaurant in Constantine offers a perfect blend of traditional Algerian cuisine and fresh seafood, served in a warm and inviting atmosphere. Enjoy flavorful tajines, couscous, and grilled seafood, paired with a selection of refreshing drinks, for an authentic and memorable dining experience.

Restaurant les Palmiers is a seafood lover’s paradise, offering the freshest grilled fish, shrimp, and seafood specialties, along with flavorful chicken dishes, rice, and traditional Algerian cuisine. To complete your meal, indulge in a delightful selection of homemade desserts, all served in a warm and inviting setting.

KS Restaurant in Constantine is the go-to spot for delicious tacos, pizza, burgers, and sandwiches, all made with fresh ingredients and bold flavors. Whether you are craving a quick bite or a full meal, their menu also features refreshing drinks and indulgent desserts, making it the perfect place to satisfy any craving in a cozy, welcoming setting
Whether you are looking for a quick bite on the go or a satisfying meal with friends, Snack Youyou delivers speed, flavor, and a vibrant atmosphere—making every visit a treat.
Constantine, next to MENTOURI University Campus
Constantine, kadri Brahim street, 04 Chemins street, 25000
